docs.title: Guide to English - Literature
docs.text: The exam board used for literature is: AQA

docs.title: Paper 1
docs.text:
This will cover:

  • Romeo and Juliet
  • Jekyll and Hyde

docs.title: Paper 2
docs.text:
This will cover:

  • An Inspector Calls
  • Unseen Poetry

docs.title: Summary
docs.text:
Jekyll & Hyde contains 10 chapters:

  • Chapter 1: Story of the Door
  • Chapter 2: Search for Mr. Hyde
  • Chapter 3: Dr. Jekyll Was Quite At Ease
  • Chapter 4: The Carew Murder Case
  • Chapter 5: Incident of the Letter
  • Chapter 6: Remarkable Incident of Dr. Lanyon
  • Chapter 7: Incident at the Window
  • Chapter 8: The Last Night
  • Chapter 9: Dr. Lanyon's Narrative
  • Chapter 10: Henry Jekyll's Full Statement of the Case

docs.title: Key themes
docs.text:
These include:

  • Good and Evil/Duality of Man
    • Superego - part of person that has conscience of ethics and morals and being able to make decisions
    • Id - animalistic natures of a person
  • Class hierachy
  • Secrecy/Barriers
  • Animalism
  • Reputation
  • Supernatural
  • Repression
  • Science
  • Religion
  • Victorian era values
    • They're a pretty hierarchal and patriarchal society

docs.title: Dr. Jekyll was Quite at Ease
Henry Jekyll's Full Statement of the Case
"one a little man"
docs.text: • Playing with victorian expectations

docs.title: "stumping along eastwards"
docs.text:
• Stumping - walking irreguarly, stiffly, sense of deformity
  • Eastwards is a biblical allusion referring to the East of Eden, land of sinners

docs.title: "the man trampled calmly over the child's body and left her screaming on the ground. It sounds nothing to hear, but hellish to see"
docs.text:
• Oxymoron of trampling calmly gives thde impression of Hyde finding it easy to disregard human life painting him as merciless and emotionless
  • Screaming emphaises on the pain that Hyde inflicted on her
  • Juxtaposition of nothing to hear, regarding it as unimportant and hellish to see invoking a visceral reaction due to human nature

docs.title: "it wasn't like a man; it was like some damned juggernaut"
docs.text:
• Use of the pronoun, 'it' suggests Hyde as non-human, foreign or unnatural
  • Juggernaut shows something powerful, indestructible and reckless

docs.title: "one look, so ugly that it brought out the sweat on me like running"
docs.text:
• Ugly is connoting to evil
  • Hyde has an intimidating look that is so intimidating it makes a person nervous

docs.title: "I had taken a loathing to my gentleman at first sight"
docs.text: • The sight of Hyde is so detestable it invokes a visceral reaction right away

docs.title: "the man... with a kind of black sneering coldness - frightened too"
docs.text:
• Hyde takes a mocking attitude to the men, disregarding them, emotionless for he had done
  • However when his reputation is threatened, he becomes frightened

docs.title: "really like Satan"
docs.text: • Hyde is compared to devil, evil

docs.title: "something wrong with his appearance; something displeasing, something detestable"
docs.text:
• Hyde is regarding as inhuman with the repetition of 'something'
  • Hyde as usually invokes a visceral reaction to people who lay sight on him, described as disgusting

docs.title: "It was worse when it began to be clothed upon with destestable attributes; out of the shifting, insubstanial mists that had so long baffled his eye, there leaped up the sudden, definite presentment of a fiend"
docs.text:
• Figurative language connotes to a image of a monster
  • Mists - symbolic to reflect about the mystery of the plot and about Hyde

docs.title: "odd light footsteps"
docs.text: • Hyde is degenerated, underdeveloped, deformed

docs.title: "Hyde shrank back with a hissing intake of breath"
docs.text:
• Zoomorphism relating to a snake
    • This relates to the Bible in revelations where a great dragon, a serpent, was cast out dubbed the Devil or Satan as the Great Deceiver

docs.title: "the other snarled aloud into a savage laugh"
docs.text:
• Zoomorphism - snarled is an aggressive growl similar to an angry voice
  • Savage - derived from a word for native people, relates to the fear of the unknown

docs.title: "with extraordinary quickness"
docs.text: • Supernatural

docs.title: "[Utterson] putting his hand to his brow like a man in mental perplexity"
docs.text:
• Hyde has an unsettling nature that Utterson had to contemplate about it
  • Simile: Utterson contrasts his character from before from being calm and collected to being puzzled

docs.title: "he gave an impression of deformity without any nameable malformation"
docs.text:
• Hyde physically doesn't seem deformed
  • Hyde could be deformed somewhere else such as mentally
  • Hyde could be too perplexing for one to analyse

docs.title: "muderous mixture of timidity and boldness"
docs.text: • Oxymoron and paradoxical, timidity and boldness - presents Hyde as unpredictable and dangerous in the word "murderous"

docs.title: "unknown disgust, loathing and fear"
docs.text: • Triple: Hyde cannot be explained, something supernatural and people get this feeling around Hyde, a sense of "deformity"

docs.title: "something troglodytic"
docs.text: • Troglodytic - early human, Darwin's theory suggests underdevelopment and deformity

docs.title: "foul soul that thus transpires through"
docs.text: • Feeling of degeneracy

docs.title: "I read Satan's signature upon a face"
docs.text: • Parallels Hyde and the Devil, they are the same in comparable qualities - Hyde is associated with evil

docs.title: "Hyde... for whom she had conceived a dislike"
docs.text: • Hyde's presence imposes on who sees him a feeling of prejudice to dislike him as his presence is "evil"

docs.title: "but he answered never a word"
docs.text: • Hyde's silence suggests that the attack on Carew was thought out without a good argument or reason for why he attacks him, pure evil

docs.title: "seemed to listen with an ill-contained impatience"
docs.text:
• Hyde's impaitence with others is barely contained, he fails to hide it and lets it slip out
  • Opposite to a Victorian gentleman, who is supposed to be paitent and polite

docs.title: "[Hyde] broke out in a great flame of anger, stamping with his foot"
docs.text:
• A metaphor describing his anger
    • Described as a flame linking to Hell, Hell's flame is inextinguishable (eternal) relating to Hyde's anger, it cannot be stopped, indestructible
  • Stamping the verb enhances to visciousness of Hyde's attack aswell the attack being vindictive, no reason for it to be happening, Hyde is just evil

docs.title: "like a madman"
docs.text: • Hyde's behaviour has changed to a violent, insane lunatic

docs.title: "[Hyde] broke all bounds and clubbed him to the earth"
docs.text:
• Hyde rejecting the Victorian gentlemen expectations completely, pure evil is acting
  • Clubbed the verb enhances the visciousness of Hyde's attack

docs.title: "with ape-like fury"
docs.text: • Zoomorphism - compared to an ape, underdeveloped human, linking to Darwinism showing the attack to be without reason and pure evil

docs.title: "[Hyde] was trampling his victim under foot and hailing a storm of blows"
docs.text: • The verbs trampling and hailing enhances the visciousness of his attack

docs.title: "under which the bones were audibly shattered"
docs.text: • The onomatopoeia can be imagined by the reader which enhances the visciousness of the attack

docs.title: "his victim... incredibly mangled"
docs.text: • This enhances the visciousness of the attack, depicting Carew as prey that Hyde had hunted on - animalistic, Hyde is a predator

docs.title: "insensate cruelty"
docs.text: • The attack was without reason, Hyde did this attack under pure evil

docs.title: "A flash of odious joy appeared upon the woman's face"
docs.text: • Hyde is disliked by many of whom see him

docs.title: "The man... was mad"
docs.text: • Uncontrollable, unpredictable as seen in Utterson's encounter with Hyde in this quote

docs.title: "Much of his past was unearthed"
docs.text: • Unearthed relates to secrecy

docs.title: "all disreputable: tales came out of the man's cruelty... so callous and violent"
docs.text:
• The stories about Hyde's deeds are all regarded as unacceptable
  • The acts he had done are cruel, insensitive and violent to others

docs.title: "the body of a man sorely contorted and still twitching"
docs.text: • Imagery of horror and agony

docs.title: "He was dressed in clothes far too large for him"
docs.text: • Clues, foreshadowing to Hyde's identity reveal

docs.title: "body of a selfdestroyer"
docs.text:
• selfdestroyer is suicide, a sin
    • Some softened up in their attitudes to suicide at the time

docs.title: "volatile"
docs.text: • Relates to his temper - short lived

docs.title: "a small man crouching against a pillar"
docs.text: • Animalistic - ready to pounce

docs.title: "I was struck besides with the shocking expression of his face, with his remarkable combination of great muscular activity and great apparent debility of constitution"
docs.text: • Disturbed by Hyde's appearance, a common occurence

docs.title: "the waist of his coat below his haunches, and the collar sprawling wide upon his collar"
docs.text: • Clues to Hyde's identity, same clothes as Jekyll in Chapter 8

docs.title: "there was something abnormal and misbegotten"
docs.text:
• Victorian anxiety of the "other"
  • Hyde is inhuman

docs.title: "the creature"
docs.text: • Zoomorphism

docs.title: "something seizing, suprising and revolting"
docs.text: • Sibilance - usually used when describing Hyde

docs.title: "My visitor was, indeed on fire with sombre excitement"
docs.text:
• Hyde's desperation, reflecting Jekyll's letter
  • Fire has connotations of danger

docs.title: "a certain icy pang along my blood"
docs.text: • Replusion Hyde invokes into others whom witness him

docs.title: "my impaitence has shown its heels to my politeness"
docs.text: • Juxtaposing words, foreshadowing Hyde's identity reveal

docs.title: "Will you be wise? Will you be guided?"
docs.text:
• Arrogance displayed by Hyde
  • Jekyll's contempt for Lanyon being conventional instead of exploring ideas leaks into Hyde's personality

docs.title: "or the has the greed of curiosity too much command of you?"
docs.text:
• Biblical language
    • Danger of curiosity
    • Sin of temptation

docs.title: "he reeled, staggered, clutched at the table and held on"
docs.text: • Visual description used to create imagery of pain and horror

docs.title: "drinking pleasure... from any degree of torture to another"
docs.text: • Sadistic

docs.title: "[In Jekyll's will] his possessions were to pass into the hands of his "friend and benefactor Edward Hyde""
docs.text:
• Jekyll and Hyde relationship akin to a father-son relationship
  • Benefactor foreshadows the reveal of Jekyll = Hyde, Chapter 10 explores the idea of Hyde helping Jekyll with his repressed desires

docs.title: "he now sat on the opposite side of the fire"
docs.text:
• The fire could relate to the imagery of Hell, relating to Hyde as Hell are where sinners reside
  • The fire could be tempting Jekyll to enjoy the liberty as being Hyde as described in Chapter 10 as fires have warm, welcoming embraces

docs.title: "a large, well-made, smooth-faced man of fifty, with something of a stylish cast perhaps"
docs.text:
Info

Some sources may say "slyish cast" or "stylish cast", be careful with that, for the source i have, it says "stylish cast"

  • The first part of the quote depicts Jekyll as a traditional Victorian gentleman
  • The second part shows Jekyll as sophisticated but something mysterious under that persona identified by the adverb "perhaps" making it less definite

docs.title: "every mark of capacity of kindness"
docs.text: • Shows Jekyll as being capable and compassionate - sterotypical of a Victorian gentleman

docs.title: "A close observer might have gathered that the topic was distasteful; but the doctor carried it off gaily"
docs.text: • Someone would have noticed that the topic was unpleasant however Jekyll plays it off light-heartedly, concealing something that he doesn't want anyone to know

docs.title: "hide-bound pendant [Lanyon]"
docs.text:
• Jekyll describes Lanyon as someone who obsesses over minor details about science who is unwilling to change due to conventions/tradition
  • Lanyon acts as Jekyll's foil

docs.title: "scientific heresies"
docs.text: • Lanyon views Jekyll's science as wrong and "balderdash" - nonsense, considering his work heretical

docs.title: "[Jekyll] grew pale to the very lips, and there came blackness about his eyes"
docs.text: • Jekyll is hiding something about Hyde that he does not want Utterson wanting to know therefore passing off the topic of his will containing Hyde gaily - lightheartedly

docs.title: "the moment I choose to, I can be rid of Hyde"
docs.text: • This is ironic as we see in Chapter 10 that the drug that Jekyll had been taken to repress Hyde has stopped working, leading to Hyde completely overtaking Jekyll

docs.title: "[Jekyll] close up to the warmth sat Dr. Jekyll, looking deathly sick"
docs.text:
• Jekyll being close up the warmth is seeking the light, almost looking to repent for something, striving the path of righteousness
  • Deathly sick contrasts Jekyll in Chapter 3 where he is described as a large, well-made, smooth-faced man of fifty, with something of a stylish cast perhaps

docs.title: "I was thinking of my own character, which this hateful business has rather exposed"
docs.text:
• Hateful business is a euphemism in place for the murder of Carew which he chooses not to say
  • Shows Jekyll caring for his reputation in his own character

docs.title: "there's a singular resemblance; the two hands are in many points identical; only differently sloped"
docs.text:
• Raises suspicions - this foreshadows the reveal of Jekyll and Hyde being the same character
  • Suggests that Hyde is left handed - in Victorian times this was seen as an abnormality, being a sign of the devil

docs.title: "whilst he was known for charities, he was now no less distinguished for religion"
docs.text: • Jekyll had followed the path of the light and appeared as a new person, having repented for his actions

docs.title: "he was much in the open air... his face seemed to open"
docs.text: • The repetition of open contrasts the previously secluded and less open Jekyll as seen in Chapter 3 and Chapter 5, this contrasts with the reoccuring theme of barriers

docs.title: "the door was shut against the lawyer"
docs.text: • Contrasts the more open Jekyll seen previously, returned to his secluded life with the motif of barriers/secrecy

docs.title: "I mean from henceforth to lead a life of extreme seclusion"
docs.text: • Jekyll is leading his life of seclusion again, reoccuring of barriers

docs.title: "You must suffer me to go my own dark way"
docs.text: • The reader is reminded of Utterson's words "I let my brother go to the devil in his own way"

docs.title: "I have brought on myself a punishment and a danger that I cannot name"
docs.text: • Brought upon his fate by himself

docs.title: "If I am the chief of sinners, I am the chief of sinners also"
docs.text:
• Juxtaposes each other, the parallels here invokes mystery due to the internal conflict has, respectable side and Hyde
  • Biblical reference, Paul the Apostle, described himself as the chief of sinners, reflects Jekyll's struggle with morals

docs.title: "The doctor... now more than ever confined himself to the cabinet... where he would sometimes sleep; he was out of spirits, he had grown very silent, he did not read"
docs.text:
• Jekyll's condition physically and mentally have been getting worse
  • Semantics of imprisonment, contrasting Utterson who prefers to speak to Poole outside of Jekyll's house

docs.title: "like some disconsolate prisoner"
docs.text: • Smile comparing Jekyll to a prisoner, stuck in his cell, the cabinet above his lab

docs.title: "sighed... it is quite impossible; I dare not"
docs.text: • Jekyll is feeling hopeless, showing his gradual decline in health

docs.title: "words were hardly uttered, before the smile was struck out of his face and suceeded by an expression of such abject terror and despair"
docs.text:
• The verb struck is violent, shocking and unexpected
    • This also mirrors the verb used to describe Carew's murder, foreshadowing Jekyll = Hyde

docs.title: "the window was instantly thrust down"
docs.text:
• The verb thrust creates a sense of panic
  • This is a dramatic reaction akin to Hyde

docs.title: "Lanyon my life, my honour, my reason, are all at your mercy; if you fail me to-night, I am lost"
docs.text: • Jekyll demonstrates desperation and vulnerability and places responsibility on Lanyon

docs.title: "I want you to postpone all other engagements for tonight, even if you were summoned to a bedside of an emperor; to take a cab... with this letter... and drive straight to my house"
docs.text: • Hyperbole enforces the importance of this task Jekyll gave Lanyon

docs.title: "The door of my cabinet is then to be forced"
docs.text: • Relates to Chapter 8 when Hyde was revealed to be in there

docs.title: "At midnight"
docs.text: • Represents the end of the day, foreshadows the death of them both

docs.title: "labouring under a blackness of distress"
docs.text: • Metaphor: Jekyll is struggling with something

docs.title: "Jekyll's private manufacture"
docs.text: • Attempts to play God, relates to Frankenstein

docs.title: "fond of the respect of the wise and good among my fellowmen"
docs.text: • Respected gentleman of wealth

docs.title: "and thus... with every guarantee of an honourable and distinguished future"
docs.text: • Others sought respect

docs.title: "Many a man would have even blazoned such irregularities as I was gulity of"
docs.text:
• Jekyll's arrogance about his willpower
  • Victorian repression

docs.title: "served in me those provinces of good and ill which divide and compound man's dual nature"
docs.text: • Already living a double life

docs.title: "I was no more myself when I laid restraint and plunged in shame than when i laboured... at the furtherance of knowledge or the relief of sorrow and suffering"
docs.text: • Struggles to resist temptations

docs.title: "that man is not truly one, but truly two"
docs.text: • Repeats truly to enforce Jekyll's discovery about nature of man

docs.title: "primitive duality of man"
docs.text:
• Darwinism
  • Victorian anxiety
  • Arrogance

docs.title: "Hyde was so much smaller, slighter and younger than Henry Jekyll"
docs.text: • Symbolises his physical manifestation of his inner darkness

docs.title: "I was conscious of no repugance, rather of a leap of welcome... it seemed natural and human"
docs.text: • Embraces his other side - the "id"

docs.title: "Hence, although I had two characters as well as two appearances, one was wholly evil and the other was still the old Henry Jekyll"
docs.text:
• Hyde is evil and Jekyll is himself
  • His experiment had failed and did not seperate the evil side

docs.title: "I had not conquered my aversions to the dryness of a life of study"
docs.text: • Forced

docs.title: "It was on this side that my new power tempted me until I fell into slavery"
docs.text: • Jekyll is a prisoner to himself, tempted by youthful freedom and indulgence as Hyde

docs.title: "I began to profit by the strange immunities of my position"
docs.text: • Enjoyed the benefits of being Hyde

docs.title: "Like a schoolboy, strip off these lendings and spring headlong into the sea of liberty"
docs.text: • Being Hyde was freeing to Jekyll as if being a child, without any responsibility

docs.title: "The situation was apart from ordinary laws, and insidiously relaxed the grasp of conscience. It was Hyde, after all, and Hyde alone, that was gulity"
docs.text: • Does not take responsibility of the actions of Hyde

docs.title: "And thus, his conscience slumbered"
docs.text:
• Hyde is a seperate part of Jekyll
    • Crimes as Hyde doesn't affect Jekyll

docs.title: "It was the hand of Edward Hyde"
docs.text: • Jekyll is involuntarily turning into Hyde in his sleep, losing control over himself

docs.title: "That part of me which I had the power of projecting, had lately been much exercised and nourished"
docs.text: • Hyde is growing evil which is affecting Jekyll as well

docs.title: "the balance of my nature might be permanently overthrown, the power of voluntary change be forfeited, and the character of Edward Hyde become irrevocably mine"  "that I was slowly losing hold of my original and beter self and becoming slowly incorporated with my second and worse"
docs.text: • Jekyll is losing control over Hyde, Hyde is gaining more power over the body

docs.title: "Between these two, I now felt I had to choose"
docs.text: • Reflects Stevenson choice on religion

docs.title: "I chose the better part and was found wanting in the strength to keep to it"
docs.text:
• Stays as Jekyll
  • Resisting temptation to go back to being Hyde

docs.title: "I began to be tortured with throes and longings"
docs.text:
• Victimises himself
  • Drug addiction - reflects on Stevenson

docs.title: "My devil had been long caged, he came out roaring"
docs.text:
• Metaphor with hellish language
  • Came out roaring links to Victorian repression, desires were repressed to look good in the public eye

docs.title: "ecstasy of mind, gloating on my crime, light-headly devising others in the future"
docs.text: • Hyde takes a form of pleasure from crimes, sadism from Carew's murder

docs.title: "Hyde was thenceforth impossible; whether I would or not, I was now confined to the better part of my existence; and O, how I rejoiced to think of it"
docs.text:
• Jekyll has good reason to remain as himself
    • Hyde is wanted for murder
  • Only drops the act when it threatens his safety

docs.title: "no, it was in my own person that I was once more tempted to triffle with my conscience; and it was an ordinary secret sinner that I at last fell before the assaults of temptation"
docs.text: • Hyde has corrupted Jekyll, Jekyll falls into temptation

docs.title: "I was once more Edward Hyde"
docs.text: • Jekyll has involuntarily transformed in Hyde, showing his loss of control

docs.title: "It took on this ocassion a double dose to recall me to myself"
docs.text: • Jekyll is loosing control quicker

docs.title: "as I sat looking sadly into the fire, the pangs returned"
docs.text: • Sibilance announces Hyde's presence

docs.title: "only under the immediate stimulation of the drug, that I was able to wear the countenance of Jekyll"
docs.text: • Metaphor - suggests Jekyll is the clothing and Hyde is the true self after corrupting Jekyll

docs.title: "a creature eaten up and emptied by fever, languidly weak both in body and mind"
docs.text:
• Powerless - contrasts the beginning of the trials
  • Ambiguous language to himself, loosing control

docs.title: "The powers of Hyde seemed to grown with the sickness of Jekyll"
docs.text: • Survival of the Fittest

docs.title: "His terror of the gallows drove him continually to commit temporary suicide, and return to his subordinate station of a part instead of a person"
docs.text: • For Hyde, suicide means hiding in Jekyll, for Jekyll it means death

docs.title: "When I know how he fears my power to cut him off by suicide, I find it in my heart to pity him"
docs.text:
• More pity in his Hyde than his victims, corrupted by Hyde
  • Father-Son relationship

docs.title: "I am now persuaded that my first supply was impure and that it was that unknwon impurity which lent efficacy to the draught"
docs.text:
• Jekyll realises that the drug doesn't have the impurity and cannot replicate it.
  • His fate is sealed for attempting to play God

docs.title: "Will Hyde die upon the scaffold? Or will he find courage to release himself at the last moment... this is my true hour of death"
docs.text:
• Uncertainty, loses control.
  • Sought knowledge beyond man (cautionary tale)

docs.title: "if anyone knows, it will be Lanyon," he had thought
docs.text: • Reader is established to be trusting Lanyon

docs.title: "[Lanyon] was a hearty, healthy, dapper, red-faced gentleman, with a shock of hair prematurely white and a boisterous and decided manner"
docs.text:
• Contrasts to the presentation of his character in Chapter 6
  • Presented as a healthy and optimistic man

docs.title: "At sight of Mr. Utterson he sprang up from his chair and welcomed him with both hands"
docs.text:
• Warm and inviting welcome
  • Traditional - links to his view of science and the traditional sense of a Victorian gentleman, polite

docs.title: "Henry Jekyll had became too fanciful for me"
docs.text:
• Lanyon is presented as conventional and traditional man of science
  • Jekyll wants to break free of the convention and tradition, Lanyon sees this as unrealistic

docs.title: "Such unscientific balderdash"
docs.text: • Lanyon views Jekyll's scientific discoveries as unexplainable and nonsense

docs.title: "would have estranged Damon and Pythias"
docs.text:
• Damon and Pythias was an ancient greek story about two inseperable friends
  • Oxymoron implying the deep and irreparable rift between Lanyon and Jekyll

docs.title: "He had his death-warrant written legibly upon his face"
docs.text: • Foreshadows Lanyon's death

docs.title: "[Lanyon] had grown pale; his flesh had fallen away; he was visibly balder and older; and yet it was not so much these tokens of a swift physical decay"
docs.text:
• Lanyon depicted as sickly, vulnerable and weak with physical decay having connotations of death, foreshadowing his death
  • Lanyon's appearance is greatly contrasted when he was described as a hearty, healthy, dapper, red-faced gentleman, with a shock of hair prematurely white and a boisterous and decided manner

docs.title: "a look in the eye... seemed to testify to some deep-seated terror of the mind"
docs.text: • Lanyon has had a major shock, mentally unstable

docs.title: "Lanyon declared himself a doomed man"
docs.text: • He is hopeless and know his death is soon, foreshadows his death

docs.title: ""I have had a shock"... "and I shall never recover""
docs.text:
• He has seen something that he shouldn't have
  • Declares his fate, foreshadows his death

docs.title: ""I wish to see or hear no more of Dr. Jekyll," he said in a loud, unsteady voice"
docs.text:
• His tone is impassioned, full of anger/detestation against Jekyll
  • Loud unsteady voice is a oxymoron with loud being declarative and unsteady being unsure, this gives an effect of Lanyon's fear/anxiety

docs.title: ""I am quite done with that person; and I beg that you will spare me any allusion to one whom I regard as dead.""
docs.text:
• The noun phrase of "that person"
    • Reluctance of Laynon to dignify Jekyll with a name
    • "That" shows disgust
  • The hyperbole "one whom i regard as dead" is an unintentional foreshadowing to Jekyll's death

docs.title: "I made sure my colleague was insane; but till that was proved beyond the possibility of doubt, I felt bound to do as he requested"
docs.text:
• Lanyon is sympathetic and shows pity
  • Bound by honour to do his friend's bidding

docs.title: "be set aside without a grave responsibility"
docs.text:
• Connotations to death
  • Foreshadowing to both of their fates

docs.title: "I loaded an old revolver"
docs.text:
• The revolver is a weapon symbolising death
  • Ironic that it is used in self defense however it fails to protect Lanyon and he succumbs to shock

docs.title: "I have gone too far in the way of explicable services to pause before I see the end"
docs.text:
• Gives into temptation
  • Weak nature of man

docs.title: "My life is shaken to it's roots; sleep has left me"
docs.text:
• Metaphor
  • Personification and sibilance - Jekyll/Hyde's influence left on Lanyon

docs.title: ""You know the doctor's ways, sir" replied Poole, "and how he shuts himself up. Well he's shut up again in the cabinet; and I don't like it, sir - I wish I may die if I like it. Mr. Utterson, sir, I'm afraid.""
docs.text:
• repetition of "sir" reminds of the differing class statuses, the repetition is also used to convey Poole's panic
  • When Poole mentions how Jekyll shuts himself up, this contrasts how he was open before
  • The hyperbole of "I wish I may die if I like it" reveals the extent of Poole's horror

docs.title: "mopped his brow with a red pockethandkerchief"
docs.text: • Red has connotations to danger

docs.title: "strangling anguish; for his face was white and his voice... harsh and broken"
docs.text: • Imagery of terror and death

docs.title: "[Poole] knocked in a guarded manner"
docs.text: • Being cautious

docs.title: "Now sir... you come as gently as you can. I want you to hear and I don't want you to be heard... if by any chance he was to ask you in, don't go"
docs.text:
• Rigid Victorian class sytem
  • Poole subverts this using imperatives
  • Natural order of Victorian society is being upturned

docs.title: "him, or it; whatever it is that lives in the cabinet, has been crying night and day for some sort of medicine and cannot get it to his mind"
docs.text: • Poole uses the ambiguous language of "him or it" to describe what is hiding in the cabinet (it's Hyde), he is unsure if whatever is inside is human or not, he suggests this by ammending "him" to "it"

docs.title: "he was at the far end of the room digging among the crates. He looked up when I came in, gave a kind of cry and whipped upstairs"
docs.text:
• Digging is zoomorphic verb, zoomorphism is common when describing Hyde, suggests he is a scavenger, returning to prehistoric man
  • Whipped suggests animalistic traits, common with Hyde, going up with animalistic speeds
  • a kind of cry suggests it is not human, a creature relating to Hyde

docs.title: "the hair stood upon my head like quills"
docs.text:
• Zoomorphic simile - fear from seeing Hyde, common trope
  • Hyde's animalistic nature is infectious

docs.title: "why did he cry out like a rat"
docs.text: • Simile - compares Hyde to vermin

docs.title: ""My master... is a tall fine build of a man and this was more of a dwarf""
docs.text: • Dwarf is embodiment of Victorian anxieties about evolution, it represents physical degeneration

docs.title: ""Well when that masked thing like a monkey jumped from among the chemicals and whipped into the cabinet, it went down my spine like ice""
docs.text:
• Poole uses ambiguous language to describe Hyde, "thing" is ambiguous relating to Hyde's inhuman nature, being supernatural
  • The simile compares Hyde to a monkey relating to Darwinism in an animalistic way

docs.title: "it drove a thriving trade"
docs.text: • Lively, busy and full of life

docs.title: "laying out the surplus of grains in coquetry"
docs.text:
• Large amount of grain, higher class
  • Grains are appealing

docs.title: "air of intivitation, like rows of smiling saleswomen"
docs.text: • The enviroment is personified and compared using a simile to being warm, friendly and welcoming

docs.title: "the street shone out in contrast to its dingy neighbourhood, like a fire in a forest"
docs.text:
• The street juxtaposes the run-down, gloomy neighbourhood shining like a light
  • The simile helps the juxtaposition with providing the street as warm and inviting compared to the hostile neighbourhood
  • The "fire" can be presented as a foreshadowing to Hyde's reveal and later actions in Chapter 4

docs.title: "freshly painted shutters, well-polished brasses and general cleanliness and gaiety of note, instantly caught and pleased the eye of the passenger"
docs.text:
• The street is more cared for and paid attention to without letting the beauty decay
  • The cheerfulness is something that is notable (gaiety of note)
  • Appealing to a person

docs.title: "a certain sinister block of building thrust forward it's gable on the street"
docs.text:
• Sinster - evil
  • Thrust being a verb is an aggressive action, being forceful instead of the street where it shines

docs.title: "showed no window, nothing but a door on the lower storey and a blind forehead of discoloured wall"
docs.text:
• No windows makes the house unwelcoming
  • Blind forehead personifies as having no features, particularly the windows giving a sense of no living inhabinants inside
  • Discoloured wall gives the effect of the house not being cared for which contrasts the "frehsly painted shutters" of the other street

docs.title: "bore in every feature, marks of prolonged and sordid negligence"
docs.text: • Showed long term signs of "dishonourable" neglect, treated as scrap, no attempt to repair these marks

docs.title: "The door, which was equipped with neither bell nor knocker was blistered and distained"
docs.text:
• Unwelcoming
  • TAhe door's material is peeling off and discoloured, showing signs of neglect

docs.title: "Tramps slouched into the recess and struck matches on the panels; children kept shop upon the steps; the schoolboy had tried his knife on the mouldings; and for close on a generation"
docs.text:
• Homeless people resided in the recess showing the neglect was done for a significantly longer period of time
  • Children hung out on the shop
  • The marks made by the schoolboy had not been repaired
  • Generation emphaises the period of time

docs.title: "no one had appeared to drive away these random vistors or repair their ravages"
docs.text: • The house is abandoned and neglected

docs.title: "the face of the fogged city moon"
docs.text:
• Personifies the moon using pathetic fallacy of the scene's mood
  • Fog represents the concealed nature about the case and the mystery of Hyde, finding more about him

docs.title: "It was a fine dry night; frost in the air, the streets as clean as a ballroom floor; the lamps, unshaken by any wind, drawing a regular pattern of light and shadow"
docs.text:
• Pathetic fallacy gives the effect of mystery
  • Oxymoron - light and shadow

docs.title: "low growl of London"
docs.text: • Zoomorphism

docs.title: "small sounds carried far; domestic sounds"
docs.text: • The sibilance of small sounds gives an eerie effect

docs.title: "he gave a number of a street in Soho"
docs.text: • Soho is a unpleasant side of London full of criminality and poverty

docs.title: "[Jekyll's house] which were a great air of wealth and comfort though it was now plunged in darkness"
docs.text:
• Duality - great air of wealth representing Jekyll and the darkness representing Hyde
  • Foreshadows Jekyll's predicament

docs.title: "the first fog of the season"
docs.text:
• Patheic fallacy
    • Reflects on the Great Smog of London
    • Happens directly after the description of Carew's murder
    • The smog being man-made makes it unnatural

docs.title: "a great chocolated-coloured pall lowered over heaven"
docs.text:
• A pall is a cloth spread over a coffin
    • Links to Carew's murder
  • Lowered over heaven links to evil

docs.title: "the wind was continually charging and routing these embattled vapours"
docs.text: • Use of war imagery on the weather with pathetic fallacy

docs.title: "[Utterson] beheld a marvelous number of degrees and hues of twilight"
docs.text: • Enhances the mystery and obscurity of the plot

docs.title: "glow of rich, lurid brown like the light of some strange conflagration"
docs.text:
• The fog was unnatural
    • Enhanced by "lurid" and "strange"
  • Simile comparing it to Hell fires

docs.title: "[Utterson] crossed the theatre, once crowded with eager students, now lying gaunt and silent"
docs.text:
• Juxtaposes each other, full of life, now desolate and neglected
  • Shows Jekyll's reputation

docs.title: "a door covered with red baize"
docs.text:
• The door to Jekyll's cabinet is covered in red which connotes to danger
  • Foreshadows Hyde's occupation of the cabinet

docs.title: "The fog still slept on the wing of above the drowned city"
docs.text:
• Personifies the fog as "sleeping", being a daily occurence as humans sleep
  • Drowned implies the city is concealed and hidden, giving a mysterious atmosphere

docs.title: "the lamps glimmered like carbuncles; through the muffle and smother"
docs.text: • The fog is so thick and dense that the lamps appear as unpleasant red swollen spots (carbuncles = cluster of boils)

docs.title: "the colour grows richer in stained windows; and the glow of the hot autumn afternoons on hillside vineyards was ready to be set free and to disperse the fogs of London"
docs.text:
• The colours are bright passing through the stained glass windows contrasting the gloomy fog outside
  • The glow of the hot autumn afternoons on hillside vineyards invokes a feeling of warmth and security
  • To disperse the fogs of London depicts there is hope

docs.title: "the by-street; and that when they came infront of the door"
docs.text: • Cyclical return to the opening of the novella, back to the door

docs.title: "The court was very cool and a little damp, and full of premature twilight"
docs.text:
• Creates an eerie atmosphere
    • twilight - obscurity

docs.title: "it was a wild, cold, seasonable night of March, with a pale moon, lying on her back as though the wind had tilted her, and a flying wrack of the most diaphanous and lawny texture"
docs.text:
• Wild an adjective refers to animalistic features which can suggest to Hyde's reveal in Jekyll's cabinet later
  • Eerie atmosphere
  • Personification of the moon, the moon on "her back" paints vulnerability

docs.title: "flecked the blood into the face"
docs.text: • Image of horror and chilling, contributes to the eerie atmosphere

docs.title: "a crushing anticipation of calamity"
docs.text:
• Foreshadowing and building tension to a calamity
  • A calamity is a major event, this relates to the grand reveal of whos in the cabinet and Hyde killing himself

docs.title: "the thins trees... were lashing themselves along the railing"
docs.text:
• Lashing refers to whipping themselves, self-harm.
  • Personification

docs.title: "biting weather"
docs.text: • Zoomorphism - the weather is wild and feral

docs.title: "the lawyer"
docs.text: • Professional and educated

docs.title: "a man of rugged countenance that was never lighted by a smile; cold, scanty and embarassed in discourse"
docs.text: • Stoic (emotionless), professional and introverted

docs.title: "yet somehow lovable"
docs.text: • Establishes trust in Utterson

docs.title: "something eminently human beaconed from his eye"
docs.text: • Beacon is a symbol of light, trust being established again and states he is a righteous person

docs.title: "he was austere with himself"
docs.text: • Serious, strict and disciplined about himself

docs.title: "though he enjoyed the theatre, had not closed the doors of one for twenty years"
docs.text: • Disciplined, able to not go to a theatre even though he "enjoyed" it

docs.title: "he had an approved tolerance of others; sometimes wondering, almost with envy, at the high pressure of spirits involved in their misdeeds"
docs.text:
• Tolerant of people and able to see their views even though he considers it wrong
  • Duality and repression: He admires with jealousy the intensity of emotion people derive from their misdeeds

docs.title: "in any extremeity inclined to help rather than to reprove"
docs.text:
• He is less to judge and sticks with the facts and help people
    • Contrasts his "cold" demeanour where he is actually caring and compassionate

docs.title: "I incline to Cain's heresy"
docs.text:
• Biblical allusion
  • Mark of Cain - if anyone dared to take vengenance on Cain, God would punish them 7 times worse than they had done to him
  • Shows Utterson is less practical and is more of a spectator, allowing people to commit misdeeds without him intervening as he believes intervening will make it worse

docs.title: "I let my brother go to the devil in his own way"
docs.text:
• Religious imagery
  • Lets people go follow their own way without Utterson intervening showing he is tolerant of people

docs.title: "frequently his fortune to be the last reputable acquaintance and the last good influence in the lives of downgoing men"
docs.text:
• He has a reputation of being a loyal friend
  • Utterson is non-judgemental and will help anyone around him even if they have sunk rock bottom

docs.title: "his affections; like ivy, were a growth of time"
docs.text:
• Simile: "like ivy"
  • His friendships are "grown" overtime
  • Like plants do, they seek the light, the light being a symbol of righteous

docs.title: "Enfield, his distant kinsman, the well-known man about town"
docs.text: • Social man, contrasts to Utterson being stoic and introverted

docs.title: "counted them the chief jewel of each week"
docs.text: • Metaphor: Uterrson and Enfield consider their Sunday walks the most precious thing

docs.title: "[Utterson] came home to his bachelor house in sombre spirits"
docs.text:
• Bachelor house - women not prevalent in the play - victorian era was a patriarchal society, dominated by men
  • Sombre spirits relates to his stoic nature

docs.title: "[Utterson] sat down to dinner without relish"
docs.text: • Did not eat dinner to enjoy, ate to survive, stoic and disciplined nature

docs.title: "when this meal was over, to sit close by the fire"
docs.text: • Seeking the light and the warmth, path of righteousness

docs.title: "There he opened his safe, took from the most private part of it a document endorsed on the envelope as Dr. Jekyll's will"
docs.text: • Links to secrecy/barriers

docs.title: "but now, his imagination also was engaged, or rather enslaved"
docs.text:
• Presents Utterson's duality as earlier in the novella, he is presented as collected and disciplined
  • This contrasts this previous character as his mind is now is focused and making the irrational decision to continue to persue Hyde while Hyde being a dangerous figure

docs.title: "tossed in the gross darkness of the night and the curtained room, Mr. Enfield's tale went by before his mind in a scroll of lighted pictures"
docs.text:
• Semantic feel of torture with the repeat of barriers, this use of barriers could be interpreted as the answer to the mystery of Hyde being shielded away
  • The tale going by before his mind in a scroll relates to how a scroll is rolled out and the story unravels, this additionally adds to the contrast of the presentation of Utterson's character before

docs.title: "Utterson began to haunt the door"
docs.text:
• Haunting is a gothic genre
  • Irony - Utterson is haunting the door as it does to him
  • Temptation of uncovering Hyde's mysteries

docs.title: "Yet his attention had never before been so sharply and decisively arrested"
docs.text: • Utterson is responding to the "odd light footsteps" to responding to a predator as prey, Hyde is presented as dangerous here, compared to a predator

docs.title: "[Utterson] only grunted in acknowledgment of the address"
docs.text: • Utterson is taking on some of the animalistic natures of Hyde

docs.title: "Your master seems to repose a great deal of trust in that young man..." resumed the other musingly
docs.text:
• This expands on Utterson's caring nature as the word "musingly" shows deep thought or contemplation
    • He cares for his friend, Jekyll, wondering if theres any ulterior motive to why Hyde has a key to Jekyll's house

docs.title: "it is an ugly business"
docs.text:
• Utterson knows that this business regarding Jekyll is messy and could lead to a scandal, threatening his reputation
    • Therefore he keeps this between Mr. Guest and himself

docs.title: "A great curiosity came on the trustee, to disregard the prohibition and dive at once to the bottom of the mysteries; but professional honour and faith to his dead friend were stringent obligations"
docs.text:
• Duality of Utterson
    • Wants to open letter
    • However, relation with Lanyon holds him back and his respect, therefore honouring his friend's wishes

docs.title: "[Utterson] preferred to speak with Poole upon the doorstep and surrounded by the air and sounds of the open city rather to be admitted into that house of voluntary bondage"
docs.text: • The semantics of freedom of Utterson contrasts the semantics of imprisonment that Jekyll "voluntary" chose to be confined in his house

docs.title: ""What, what? Are you all here?" said the lawyer peevishly. "Very irregular, very unseemly; your master would be far from pleased"
docs.text:
• repetition of questions reveals Utterson's anger, contrasting his stoic nature described in Chapter 1
  • Concerned with reputation and respectability

docs.title: ""I shall consider it my duty to break in that door""
docs.text:
• Shall is honourable
  • He is about to remove the barriers surrounding the entire play

docs.title: "I believe poor Harry is killed; and I believe his murderer is still lurking in his victim's room"
docs.text:
• Utterson refers Jekyll as "poor Harry", reminding the reader of their close relationship
  • The anaphora repetition of "I believe" demonstrates Utterson's convinction
  • This quote builds tension and is the main climax of the novella, the truth about whos in the cabinet is about to be revealed

docs.title: Summary
docs.text: Romeo and Juliet contains:

docs.title: Act 1
docs.text:
• Prologue
  • 5 scenes

docs.title: Act 2
docs.text: • 6 scenes

docs.title: Act 3
docs.text: • 5 scenes

docs.title: Act 4
docs.text: • 5 scenes

docs.title: Act 5
docs.text: • 3 scenes

docs.title: Key themes
docs.text:
These include:

  • Love and Hate
  • Family honour
  • Fate
  • Violence/Conflict
  • Elizabethan era values

docs.title: Scene 1
docs.text:
• Street battle between the Capulets and Montagues occur
  • The brawl is soonly ended by Prince Escales whom gives both families a final warning
  • Romeo, whom is a Montague confesses to his cousin, Benvolio that he is lovesick for Rosaline, whom is a Capulet

docs.title: Scene 2
docs.text: • Paris asks Lord Capulet for permission to marry Juliet

docs.title: Scene 3
docs.text: • Lady Capulet and the Nurse praises Paris and suggests that he would be a good choice for a husband

docs.title: Scene 4
docs.text: • To cure Romeo's lovesickness, Benvolio and Mercutio persuade to join Romeo to gatecrash (turn up uninvited) to the Capulet's party

docs.title: Scene 5
docs.text:
• At the party, Romeo and Juliet meet
  • Romeo forgets about Rosaline immediately as he lays eyes on Juliet
  • Tybalt then recognises Romeo as a Montague then turns for his sword
  • Lord Capulet reprimands Tybalt and he reluctantly complys with Lord Capulet's commands as he would be punished if he had not

docs.title: Scene 1
docs.text: • Romeo gives his friends a "slip" (evasion) and leaps over the wall of the Capulet's garden into it

docs.title: Scene 2
docs.text:
• From the Capulet's ochards, Romeo could see Juliet from her window where she is thinking out aloud about Romeo ("Where are thou, Romeo?" scene)
  • Romeo reveals himself to Juliet and she warns how he could be killed for that action
  • Juliet declares their relationship is "too rash, too unadvis'd, too sudden" and bids goodnight
  • Romeo offers his "love's faithful vow" in exchange for hers
  • Romeo promises to make arranagements for their wedding by 9am
  • Juliet states she will send someone to find the details about it

docs.title: Scene 3
docs.text:
• Romeo asks Friar Lawrence to marry him to Juliet
  • Friar Lawrence in exchange accuses Romeo of being a "fickle" and "shallow lover"
  • Romeo protests and says his love is genuine and mutual
  • Friar Lawrence accepts the offering hoping that it will unite the Montagues and Capulets but worries about the "haste" of the wedding
  • He advises Romeo to go "wisely and slow, they stumble that run fast" (think carefully)

docs.title: Scene 4
docs.text:
• Mercutio and Benvolio search for Romeo
  • Benvolio suggests that Tybalt sent a duelling chalenge to Romeo
  • Mercutio praises Tybalt's skills
  • Romeo arrives and he and Mercutio exchange in conversation about why he slipped away that night
  • The Nurse arrives with Peter (her servant)
  • Mercutio mocks the Nurse whom asks where she can find Romeo
  • Romeo introduces himself and Benvolio and Mercutio leaves, Romeo promises to follow
  • Nurse condemns Mercutio's actions describing him as "scurvy knave", she condemns Peter for not defending her
  • Romeo instructs the Nurse to tell Juliet to go the confessional this afternoon and asks of the Nurse to wait behind the abbey wall to receive a rope ladder Romeo will use that night to climb into Juliet's room
  • The Nurse departs to tell Juliet the news

docs.title: Scene 5
docs.text:
• Juliet waits for the Nurse's return with the news about Romeo
  • The Nurse arrives and stalls Juliet instead of telling her the news right away
  • The Nurse instructs Juliet to meet Romeo at Friar Lawrence's cell where she will become Romeo's wife

docs.title: Scene 6
docs.text:
• Friar Lawrence fears the wedding may have consequences but Romeo insists that he should marry Juliet
  • Juliet arrives and Friar Lawrence tells her both that he and Romeo should be grateful to her
  • Romeo invites Juliet to express their happiness however Juliet says her happiness is too great for words
  • Friar Lawrence then marries them

docs.title: Scene 1
docs.text:
• Mercutio refuses to leave the street and accuses Benvolio of hypocrisy, claims Benvolio is the most quarrelsome man he knows and seeking for a fight
  • As Benvolio feared, the Capulets appear, Mercutio taunts Tybalt however Tybalt remains calm
  • When Romeo arrives he states Romeo is a "villain" and challenges him to "turn and draw"
  • Romeo declines the offer for the duel as he has recently married Juliet (Tybalt is now considered Romeo's cousin in-law)
  • Mercutio is digusted by Romeo's "submission" and accepts the duel in Romeo's place
  • When Romeo attempts to stop them, Mercutio is stabbed and died
  • In anger, he fights Tybalt and kills him
  • At Benvolio's request, he runs and Prince Escales hears the report from Benvolio, he is furious that his kinsman, Mercutio had been murdered
  • He states he will heavily fine both families
  • He banishes Romeo out of Verona to reside in Mantua and if he were to return, he would be executed

docs.title: Scene 2
docs.text:
• When the Nurse arrives to Juliet, she is wailing "he's dead"
  • Juliet assumes the worst, that who "he is dead" is Romeo
  • The Nurse states the corpse was "all bedaub'd in blood"
  • She then discovered Romeo had killed Tybalt
  • Juliet is shocked by this that Romeo had been gulity of the crime describing him as "Beautiful tyrant, fiend angelical! dove-feather'd raven, wolvish-ravening lamb!"
  • The Nurse wishes shame on Romeo
  • Juliet still defends Romeo "shall I speak ill of him that is my husband?" She then points out Tybalt had been trying to kill Romeo and is comforted that Romeo is alive more than she is upset at Tybalt's death
  • Juliet realises Romeo had been banished and states words cannot express her sorrow and that she will "die maiden-widowed"
  • The Nurse reveals Romeo is hiding in Friar Lawrence's cell and she will tell Romeo to come and comfort Juliet
  • Juliet gives the Nurse a ring to give Romeo

docs.title: Scene 3
docs.text:
• Romeo seeks Friar Lawrence for help and is hiding in his cell
  • Friar Lawrence fears Romeo is enjoying is latest "calamity" (significant event)
  • Friar Lawrence tells Romeo that he should thank Prince Escales for banishing him instead of execution
  • Romeo insists that banishment is worse as death
  • Friar Lawrence tells Romeo to be paitent and not to waste time complaining about circumstances that cannot be changed, he states that madmen wont listen to advice
  • Romeo rejects Friar Lawrence's advice and implies Friar Lawrence is being unwise by ignoring his distress and not acknowledging his problems because Friar Lawrence isnt young nor in love so he cannot understand his feelings
  • The Nurse arrives and tells Romeo to "be a man" and reports that Juliet has done nothing but weep, fall down, and call out "Tybalt" then "Romeo"
  • Romeo interepts this as his name is killing Juliet and therefore tries to stab himself, the Nurse then disarms him
  • Romeo's sinful attempt of suicide engages Friar Lawrence, he tells Romeo he should be ashamed of acting like a beast or a woman
  • Friar Lawrence tells Romeo to be grateful for his "pack of blessings"
  • Friar Lawrence tells Romeo to go to Mantua until the Friar can publicise his marriage to Juliet and persuade Prince Escales to paron him
  • The Nurse is impressed by this advice as it shows he is "learning"
  • The Nurse hands Juliet's ring to Romeo and is comforted
  • Friar Lawrence warns Romeo to leave Juliet before dawn so he can safely escape to Mantua from Verona

docs.title: Scene 4
docs.text: • Lord Capulet offers Juliet to Paris to be wed to him at Thursday, 3 days later, for the wedding Lord Capulet decides on a small one for respect of Tybalt

docs.title: Scene 5
docs.text:
• Romeo spends the night with Juliet and realises it is getting light out so he must "be gone and live or stay and die"
  • When Juliet insists that is not morning, Romeo says he is willing to stay even at risk of arrest/execution
  • Juliet realises it is morning and bids Romeo to "be gone"
  • When he climbs down the rope ladder, Juliet gets a image of him in his grave (foreshadowing)
  • He reassures her before departing for Mantua
  • Lady Capulet comes in and assumes Juliet is crying that Romeo, Tybalt's murderer, is still alive. During her exchange, she replies ambigiously
  • Lady Capulet announces "good news" that Juliet's father had arranged her marriage with Paris, Juliet rejects the marriage and states she would rather marry "Romeo, whom you know I hate" than Paris
  • Lord Capulet is infuriated to hear of this rejection and threatens to drag her to the wedding, Lord Capulet condemns her actions and berates her, calling her a "curse" and threatens to throw Juliet to let her "die in the streets"
  • The Nurse attempts to calm Lord Capulet down but redirects his abuse to her
  • Juliet appeals to her mother but she replies with "Talk not to me, for i'll not speak a word. Do as thou whilt, for I have done with thee"
  • Juliet accepts the Nurse's advice to marr Paris as he is better than Romeo and he is good as dead
  • Juliet tells the Nurse to tell her parents that she will confess her sin of disobedience to Friar Lawrence
  • When the Nurse leaves, Juliet condemns her as a "wicked fiend" and visits Friar Lawrence, if he has no solution then she will kill herself

docs.title: Scene 1
docs.text:
• Friar Lawrence tells Paris he is unhappy with the "haste" of his marriage with Juliet especially as its not clear what Juliet wants
  • Paris explains that Capulet has brought the wedding forward to distract her grief from Tybalt's death
  • When Juliet arrives she avoids telling Paris she loves him, when Paris leaves, Juliet tells Friar Lawrence she is desperate enough to kill herself if he cannot save her from marrying Paris
  • Friar Lawrence tells Juliet he haas a "desperate" plan that depends on her bravery, Juliet replies that she would do anything
  • Friar Lawrence gives Juliet a potion to make her appear dead for 42 hours, while she is buried in the family's vault, Friar Lawrence will write to Romeo telling him of the plan
  • Romeo and Friar Lawrence will release her from the tomb and Romeo will take her to Mantia
  • Friar Lawrence tells Juliet the plan will work as long as she is determined and not put off by "womanish fear"

docs.title: Scene 2
docs.text:
• Lord Capulet is pleased ot hear Juliet had gone to Friar Lawrence to confess, when Juliet returns, she asks her father's forgiveness and promises to obey him in the future
  • Delighted, Lord Capulet decided to bring forward the wedding to the folowing morning, he says the whole city should be grateful to Friar Lawrence for reclaiming her from sin and forgiveness

docs.title: Scene 3
docs.text:
• Juliet sends way her mother and the Nurse, now she is overcome with mounting fears, perhaps the potion will not work or it might kill her, or she will wake up in the tomb to suffocate, driven mad by horrible sights, smells and sounds around her
  • She calms herself and drinks the potion

docs.title: Scene 4
docs.text:
• In the early hours of the morning, the Capulet household is preparing for the wedding, the Nurse and Lady Capulet try to make Lord Capulet stop interfering and go to bed
  • Suddenly, they hear Paris arriving with his muscians so Lord Capulet sends the Nurse to get Juliet ready

docs.title: Scene 5
docs.text:
• The Nurse finds Juliet deeply asleep, when she tries to wake her, the Nurse believes that Juliet is dead
  • Lady Capulet joins in with the Nurse's wailing and Lord Capulet arrives and finds the death "ties up my tongue and will not let me speak"
  • Paris aswell arrives and devastated by the "most detestable death"
  • Lord Capulet's earlier anger and revulsion towards Juliet are forgotten as "with my child, my joys are buried"
  • Friar Lawrence whom arrives with Paris tells them they should be ashamed, they wanted the best for Juliet and now she got it, "eternal life" in heaven
  • He tells them to dry their tears and prepare for Juliet's burial and funeral
  • Lord Capulet states that all the things they had gathered for the wedding will now be of use for the funeral, "all things change them to the contrary"

docs.title: Scene 1
docs.text:
• Romeo is feeling cheerful as in a dream, it foretells "some joyful news", although in this dream, Juliet found him dead, she had brought him back to life with a kiss
  • He marvels if this dream, the sweet "shadow" of love is "so rich in joy" then how sweeter the real thing will be
  • Balthasar arrives with the news Juliet is dead, "her body sleeps in the Capel's monument", he asks Romeo's forgiveness for having to bring bad news
  • Balthasar tells Romeo he holds no letters from Friar Lawrence, Romeo sends Balthasar for "ink and paper" and horses and reveals to him he is going to poison himself next to Juliet's body
  • He visits an apothecary (pharamacy), who he knows he will agree to sell Romeo a deadly poison
  • He sets for the Capulet tomb with the poison which he calls a "cordial" (pleasant tasting medicine) as it will cure him

docs.title: Scene 2
docs.text:
• Friar John who was supposed to take the letter to Romeo, brings bad news to Friar Lawrence as he was quarantined in a house as a part of plague prevention precaution so he could not deliver the letter
  • When Friar Lawrence receives this news he exclaims "unhappy fortune!"
  • Friar Lawrence immediately realises that this "may do much danger" and sends Friar John for a crowbar to break the tomb open
  • Friar Lawrence decides to write to Romeo again asking him to come back to his cell where he will keep Juliet until Romeo arrives

docs.title: Scene 3
docs.text:
• Paris arrives at Juliet's tomb, Romeo arrives, dismisses Balthasar and begins to force open the tomb
  • When Paris attempts to arrest Romeo, Romeo fights back and kills him, feeling sorry for Paris, Romeo lays his body in the tomb
  • Romeo is amazed Juliet still looks beautiful and alive, he fears that death is keeping Juliet for a lover
  • He vows to stay and protect her so he drinks the poison and dies
  • Friar Lawrence finds the bodies of Romeo and Paris, Juliet wakes up and Friar Lawrence fails to get her to come away with him
  • Hearing the watch coming, Friar Lawrence leaves
  • Juliet, finding Romeo had left her no poison, she opts for killing herself with his dagger
  • Balthasar and Friar Lawrence were caught
  • Prince Escales, Lord Montague and the Capulets arrive, Friar Lawrence explains everything that had happened and a letter that Romeo left his father confirms Friar Lawrence's account
  • In collective grief, Montague and Capulet families reconcile
  • Prince Escales announces that "some shall be pardon'd and some punished"

docs.title: Characters of Romeo and Juliet
docs.text: • Kinsman - cousin

docs.title: Neutral
docs.text:
• Prince Escales
  • Mercutio
    • Kinsman of Escales
  • Paris
    • Kinsman of Escales
  • Friar Lawerence
  • Friar John
    • Servant of Friar Lawrence
  • Nurse
    • Servant of Juliet
  • Peter
    • Servant of the Nurse
  • Balthasar
    • Servant of Romeo

docs.title: Montagues
docs.text:
• Lord and Lady
  • Benvolio
    • Newphew of Lord Montague
  • Romeo

docs.title: Capulets
docs.text:
• Lord and Lady
  • Tybalt
    • Nephew of Lady Capulet
    • Referred to as the "King of Cats"
  • Rosaline
    • Niece of Lord Capulet
  • Julie

docs.title: Kill Feed of Romeo and Juliet
Kill Feed
docs.text:
This is in order of when the deaths happen, suprisingly only 5 people die in total

  • Tybalt kills Mercutio
  • Romeo kills Tybalt
  • Romeo kills Paris
  • Romeo kills himself (poison)
  • Juliet kills herself (knife)
